awd_titl_txt: Regularity properties of stationary and evolution free boundary problems
awd_abstract_narration:
This proposal focuses on regularity issues for stationary and evolution free boundary problems. Part of this project deals with two-phase free boundary problems with distributed sources, driven by uniformly elliptic operators. We plan to develop new techniques to settle the fundamental question of whether flat or Lipschitz free boundaries are smooth. We also propose to investigate similar issues in the context of free boundary problems in the Heisenberg group, which cannot be treated within the classical framework.  Appropriate strategies will be developed to take into account the subtle geometric features of the problem. Another problem under investigation is the regularity of the moving free boundary originating in a non-homogeneous evolution problem of Stefan-type. Finally, we propose to complete the analysis of thin one phase free boundaries by investigating the question of their higher regularity (analyticity).

The free boundary problems under investigation arise in different areas of mathematics and science in general: shape optimization, combustion theory, probability and statistics among others. Typical examples of two-phase free boundary problems with distributed sources are the Prandtl-Bachelor model in fluid dynamics or the eigenvalue problem in magneto hydrodynamics. Stefan-type evolution problems describe the melting (or solidification) of a material with a solid-liquid interphase. Finally, thin free boundaries are relevant in classical physical models in mediums where long range (non-local) interactions are present, as in the propagation of surfaces of discontinuities, like planar crack expansion. A better understanding of these problems is thus of great interest to a wide scientific community.

por.por_cntn:
Free boundary (FB) problems arise in an enormous number of situations. They hold a strategic position in pure and applied sciences and thus have been the focus of considerable research over the last several decades. This proposal focused on FB problems appearing in fluid-dynamics, stochastic optimal control, flame propagation and propagation of surfaces of discontinuities, elasticity theory.

Findings of this proposal were divulged through participation to conferences, meetings and workshops. For example, we gave lectures at the Conference on Recent Trends on Elliptic Nonlocal Equations, in Toronto (June 2016) and at the 6th Symposium on Analysis and PDEs, at Purdue University, (June 2015.)

Moreover, we co-organized the Geometry and Analysis seminar at Columbia University, which gave us the opportunity to invite experts in the research area of this proposal, to exchange ideas and foster collaborations.

Also, we taught a graduate course on FB problems and we incorporated insights gained working on this proposal in our unit of “Perspectives in Mathematics”.

The key outcomes of this proposal are concerned mostly with two-phase FB problems, thin FB problems, and FB problems involving two different operators.

Two-phase FB problems appear in numerous applications, for example in the analysis of the flow of two liquids in models of jets and cavities. In a series of works, we considered two-phase FB problems governed by uniformly elliptic equations with distributed sources. We investigated the regularity of the free boundary under additional hypotheses such as flatness or Lipschitz continuity. The homogeneous case was settled in the pioneer works of Caffarelli.

 In our work, we developed a different strategy to deal with the presence of a non-zero right hand side. The key tools are a Harnack type inequality and an improvement of flatness lemma, which allow to linearize the problem.  We also provided the existence of Perron's solutions and

as an application of our results, we obtained an existence and regularity theorem for the Prandtl-Bachelor problem in fluid-dynamics.

 Another central question for two-phase problems is the optimal regularity of a solution. In the variational setting, a remarkable monotonicity formula was introduced in by Alt-Caffarelli-Friedman to establish Lipschitz continuity and to identify so called- blow-up limits. On the other hand, when the problem has a non-variational structure no known techniques are available to accomplish this task.

We investigated this issue and obtained the Lipschitz regularity of the solution in 2D, in the challenging case when the solution solves two different elliptic equations in the two phases, and the monotonicity formula is not available. One cannot expect this result to hold in such generality in higher dimensions, as a counter-example can be easily built. We also obtained a characterization of the blow-up limits and corresponding regularity results for the free boundary.

As an application we obtained the optimal regularity for solutions to the 2D Bellman’s equation that is the equation of dynamic programming for certain optimally controlled stochastic systems

Another object of investigation of this proposal was the two membranes problem. Physically the problem consists in having two elastic membranes made of possibly different composite materials that are constrained one on top of the other. The case when the two membranes are identical was widely investigated in the literature, staring with the pioneer work of Vergara Caffarelli.

The case of two different membranes is more challenging mathematically. We considered the two membranes problem for the large class of elliptic operators, possibly nonlocal, of order 2s with s in (0,1]. The interest in the nonlocal case comes from the applications. For example, in elasticity theory, when an elastic body presses against a membrane, one obtains a two membranes obstacle problem involving a fractional Laplacian and a second order operator.

In the general case, we prove a result about the Holder continuity of the solutions and we develop a viscosity solution approach. Then we obtain optimal regularity of the solutions provided that the orders of the two operators are different.

We also investigated a two membranes problem involving nonlinear operators: the classical minimal surface operator and the nonlocal s-minimal surface operator.  Also in this setting we obtained the optimal regularity of the solution pair and regularity results for the free boundary.

Finally, we investigated thin FB problems. In particular we developed the regularity theory of the  free boundary for the thin one-phase FB problem. This  problem appears in physical models in mediums where turbulence or long range interactions are present, as in flame propagation or planar crack expansion.  In a series of works we showed that the free boundary is  C^{2,\alpha} except on a small singular set of Hausdorff dimension n-3. We also obtained C^{2,\alpha} regularity of Lipschitz free boundaries. Finally, we developed Schauder estimates in so-called slit domains and obtained C^\infty regularity for C^{2,\alpha} free boundaries.
